results.name: a(n) is the exponent of the largest power of 2 that appears in the factorization of the entries in the matrix {{3,1},{1,-1}}^n.
comment: a(n) appears to equal n-1 for n not a multiple of 3.

The matrix entries of M^n, with n >= 0, are M^n(1, 1) = 2^(n-1)*F(n+3) = A063782(n), M^n(2, 2) = 2^(n-1)*F(n-3) = A319196(n), M^n(1, 2) = M^n(2, 1) = 2^(n-1)*F(n) = A085449(n), where i = sqrt(-1), F = A000045, and F(-1) = 1, F(-2) = -1, F(-3) = 2. Proof by Cayley-Hamilton, with S(n, -i) = (-i)^n*F(n+1), where S(n, x) is given in A049310. - _Wolfdieter Lang_, Oct 08 2018

The above conjecture is true. From the preceding formulas for the elements of M^n this claims that the Fibonacci numbers F(n-3), F(n) and F(n+3) are always odd for n == 1 or 2 (mod 3). This is true because F(n) is even iff n == 0 (mod 3) (see e.g. Vajda, p.73), and each of the three indices is == 1 or 2 (mod 3) for n == 1 or 2 (mod 3), respectively. - _Wolfdieter Lang_, Oct 09 2018
reference: S. Vajda, Fibonacci and Lucas numbers and the Golden Section, Ellis Horwood Ltd., Chichester, 1989, p. 73.
example: For n = 3, the matrix {{3,1},{1,-1}}^3 = {{32,8},{8,0}} and the largest power of 2 appearing in the factorization of any entry is 2^5 = 32. Hence, a(3) = 5.
